description: MTA Overview The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) IT Infrastructure is designed to be an entry level certification for people getting started in the IT career field. The Windows Operating System Fundamentals exam covers general topics related to the day-to-day operation of a Windows 7 workstation and some of the administrative tasks required to keep the machine running smoothly. Upon completing the 98-349 exam, you will be awarded the MTA IT Infrastructure certification which demonstrates to employers that you have the basic skills required to provide IT support in a help desk or field technician role.
name: MTA - Windows Operating System Fundamentals -  98-349
subtitle: Windows Operating System Fundamentals

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Ronnie give an overview of the MTA certification. This overview helps us understand who this certification is intended for and how much experience the ideal candidate is expected to have.
episodes.title: Overview of MTA
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,005 --> 00:00:06,268
[SOUND]

2
00:00:08,369 --> 00:00:11,114
The Microsoft Technical Associate
certification is one

3
00:00:11,114 --> 00:00:14,150
of the newer certifications to come from,
well, Microsoft.

4
00:00:14,150 --> 00:00:16,120
That's, that's the whole name.

5
00:00:16,120 --> 00:00:16,745
[LAUGH].

6
00:00:16,745 --> 00:00:19,935
It's the MTA, and it's a great
new certification designed for

7
00:00:19,935 --> 00:00:23,485
people that are just getting
started in the world of IT.

8
00:00:23,485 --> 00:00:26,545
There's some really big certification
names that are out there,

9
00:00:26,545 --> 00:00:31,917
like Cisco's CCNA or Microsoft's MCSE,
and those names are ubiquitous.

10
00:00:31,917 --> 00:00:36,370
Everybody knows about them any kind of
HR manager or hiring consultant is,

11
00:00:36,370 --> 00:00:38,895
is gonna recognize those
certifications and

12
00:00:38,895 --> 00:00:42,043
they bring a lot of value
to you as an IT worker.

13
00:00:42,043 --> 00:00:45,123
But if you're just getting started,
those certifications are pretty hard.

14
00:00:45,123 --> 00:00:48,853
There's a lot of information in there and
they really do expect you to have

15
00:00:48,853 --> 00:00:53,363
some real world experience already before
you jump into those certifications.

16
00:00:53,363 --> 00:00:57,517
So, if you're just getting started in IT,
if you've got a resume

17
00:00:57,517 --> 00:01:02,430
packed full of other things, not IT jobs,
how do you, how do you get in there?

18
00:01:02,430 --> 00:01:04,949
You can't just jump to those
high level certifications.

19
00:01:04,949 --> 00:01:08,490
And so
that's where the Microsoft MTA comes in.

20
00:01:08,490 --> 00:01:13,398
It's designed for people who don't
necessarily have even a single moment of

21
00:01:13,398 --> 00:01:15,524
field experience working in IT.

22
00:01:15,524 --> 00:01:19,655
But you can get in there, work with,
work with the technology, learn it,

23
00:01:19,655 --> 00:01:21,820
take the test and get certified.

24
00:01:21,820 --> 00:01:25,710
And it shows that you have a basic
level of, of skill, not just with,

25
00:01:25,710 --> 00:01:28,770
with basic computer literacy but
also with working and

26
00:01:28,770 --> 00:01:31,270
supporting Windows desktop
operating systems.

27
00:01:31,270 --> 00:01:34,940
So, this is really the first step for
somebody entering the IT,

28
00:01:34,940 --> 00:01:37,680
just career field in general,
cuz you'll jump into things like a help

29
00:01:37,680 --> 00:01:42,370
desk position, some kind of desktop
support, maybe a field repair technician.

30
00:01:42,370 --> 00:01:46,350
And this base level experience is,
is what you need just to get started.

31
00:01:46,350 --> 00:01:47,100
>> Yeah.

32
00:01:47,100 --> 00:01:51,310
Basic knowledge is what we're hoping to
convey with the Microsoft technology.

33
00:01:51,310 --> 00:01:54,890
Without the field experience, you have to
have at least the foundational knowledge.

34
00:01:54,890 --> 00:01:56,920
Microsoft wants you to get ready for that.

35
00:01:56,920 --> 00:01:59,740
And then, as you enter into the job
market, you'll actually begin to

36
00:01:59,740 --> 00:02:04,120
build more of your field experience and be
ready then for the other certifications,

37
00:02:04,120 --> 00:02:07,910
that are coming down the pipeline for
you as you get started in your IT career.

38
00:02:07,910 --> 00:02:11,360
So, that's what we're gonna be doing in
this series is helping you to build that

39
00:02:11,360 --> 00:02:15,860
foundational knowledge and
understanding of the operating system.

40
00:02:15,860 --> 00:02:18,854
>> And the other nice thing about
the MTA is if you're not certain, if,

41
00:02:18,854 --> 00:02:21,600
if you don't know if IT is
the right career field for you and

42
00:02:21,600 --> 00:02:24,980
you just wanna test the waters, right,
you just wanna give it a shot, right?

43
00:02:24,980 --> 00:02:26,740
MTA is a real low commitment.

44
00:02:26,740 --> 00:02:29,070
It's a small set of knowledge, so

45
00:02:29,070 --> 00:02:32,020
it's not like you're having to deal with
these giant books of content, right?

46
00:02:32,020 --> 00:02:34,790
So, it's a pretty manageable
set of information.

47
00:02:34,790 --> 00:02:39,110
It's one exam, and you pass that exam and
you get your certification.

48
00:02:39,110 --> 00:02:41,800
So, low commitment there too,
on the cost side.

49
00:02:41,800 --> 00:02:43,870
The exam, do you you remember Ronnie,
is it 125 or-

50
00:02:43,870 --> 00:02:44,863
>> About a $115.

51
00:02:44,863 --> 00:02:45,840
>> 115.
All right.

52
00:02:45,840 --> 00:02:48,971
So, so in, in theory,
you study, you pay a $115,

53
00:02:48,971 --> 00:02:52,340
you pass the exam and
you get the certification.

54
00:02:52,340 --> 00:02:56,480
And if you decide that IT is not right for
you, you're out a $115 and not so

55
00:02:56,480 --> 00:02:57,440
bad, right?

56
00:02:57,440 --> 00:03:01,536
So, it is a great way to get started and,
and see if IT is right for you.

57
00:03:01,536 --> 00:03:05,302
Or if you know IT is right for you, but
you just don't have a lot of experience,

58
00:03:05,302 --> 00:03:07,530
you can jump in and knock it out.

59
00:03:07,530 --> 00:03:11,252
Now, Microsoft introduced the MTA
program a little over a year ago,

60
00:03:11,252 --> 00:03:15,249
it hasn't been around all that long but
it's been very very successful.

61
00:03:15,249 --> 00:03:20,082
And they've expanded it quite a bit
from the original two exams to now where

62
00:03:20,082 --> 00:03:22,880
there's nine different exams.

63
00:03:22,880 --> 00:03:25,360
It doesn't really matter
which one you take,

64
00:03:25,360 --> 00:03:30,170
all the MTA exams when you pass
one of them, you'd get your MTA.

65
00:03:30,170 --> 00:03:32,340
So, you need to look at
the ones that are available and

66
00:03:32,340 --> 00:03:34,500
select the one that's right for you.

67
00:03:34,500 --> 00:03:39,501
Here at ITProTV, we've chosen
the operating system fundamentals exam.

68
00:03:39,501 --> 00:03:43,150
And, and let me just pull this up here, I
wanna show you guys the MTA hierarchy and,

69
00:03:43,150 --> 00:03:45,040
and this is on Microsoft's website here.

70
00:03:45,040 --> 00:03:47,980
I've just pulled up their, their MTA page.

71
00:03:47,980 --> 00:03:52,260
And as we look at it,
they show the MTA certification tracks and

72
00:03:52,260 --> 00:03:55,905
they break it up into infrastructure,
database, developer.

73
00:03:55,905 --> 00:03:56,828
All right?

74
00:03:56,828 --> 00:04:00,060
If you wanna become a programmer
working with Visual Studio,

75
00:04:00,060 --> 00:04:02,820
Visual Basic, Visual C Sharp,
and all of that,

76
00:04:02,820 --> 00:04:06,970
they've got developer MTAs that you can
jump into and they list all of those.

77
00:04:06,970 --> 00:04:07,830
There's six of them.

78
00:04:07,830 --> 00:04:09,710
They've actually added
some since I've been here.

79
00:04:09,710 --> 00:04:13,880
So, each of these, you would just take
one of these, pass that exam, and

80
00:04:13,880 --> 00:04:15,354
get your MTA.

81
00:04:15,354 --> 00:04:18,385
If you wanna be a database administrator,
well, that's a much smaller one,

82
00:04:18,385 --> 00:04:22,465
there's just one that covers
general database fundamentals.

83
00:04:22,465 --> 00:04:27,395
But for a normal IT worker, there's
gonna be a sys admin, or help desk,

84
00:04:27,395 --> 00:04:30,265
some kind of support role,
even a network engineer.

85
00:04:30,265 --> 00:04:33,825
It's IT infrastructure that we shoot for,
and IT infrastructure's

86
00:04:33,825 --> 00:04:37,930
really what the majority of
ITProTV's content centers around.

87
00:04:37,930 --> 00:04:38,630
And you'll see,

88
00:04:38,630 --> 00:04:44,180
there's four different tracks here, and
each one of them is equally important.

89
00:04:44,180 --> 00:04:48,760
If you've gonna go into the IT field,
you really should have experience, or, or

00:04:48,760 --> 00:04:50,870
knowledge in all four of these areas.

91
00:04:50,870 --> 00:04:53,160
So, no one is more

92
00:04:53,160 --> 00:04:55,870
We have
Windows Operating System Fundamentals,

93
00:04:55,870 --> 00:04:58,690
what we're gonna cover here in this show.

94
00:04:58,690 --> 00:05:01,570
We've got Windows Server

00:05:01,570 --> 00:05:03,400
Now, what's the difference there?

96
00:05:03,400 --> 00:05:08,210
Well, operating system fundamentals that's
really focused on the workstations on your

97
00:05:08,210 --> 00:05:11,340

98
00:05:11,340 --> 00:05:13,440
that's where we get to the big

99
00:05:13,440 --> 00:05:15,270
Right?
What's actually providing our web

100
00:05:15,270 --> 00:05:17,290
services, email, and, and all of that.

101
00:05:17,290 --> 00:05:22,010
It's a little bit more advanced and I,
I find generally, it's not appropriate for

102
00:05:22,010 --> 00:05:25,510
people that are just
getting started in IT.

103

Nobody's gonna hire you to work on

104
00:05:29,430 --> 00:05:32,105
experience, you normally need to
get started a little bit smaller.

105
00:05:32,105 --> 00:05:35,840
Cuz if you break a server,
you can be affecting thousands of people

106

versus if you break a desktop,
you're just affecting one person, right?

107
00:05:39,400 --> 00:05:42,387
So, that's kind of why we've leaned

108

and not the server administration at,
at that state.

109
00:05:46,110 --> 00:05:49,360
Now, the remaining two aren't unimportant,

110
00:05:49,360 --> 00:05:52,770
Networking fundamentals, almost every

111
00:05:52,770 --> 00:05:54,970
You need to be able to get out there and
communicate with the internet and

112
00:05:54,970 --> 00:05:58,000

113
00:05:58,000 --> 00:06:01,990
And security fundamentals, right,
a, a, a week barely goes by

114

that we don't hear about some major
company having a security compromise.

115
00:06:05,170 --> 00:06:07,380
So, again, very, very important.

116
00:06:07,380 --> 00:06:11,100
So, why didn't we choose to cover those?

117
00:06:11,100 --> 00:06:15,660
Well, in my opinion, and, and everybody's
opinion is, is different and may vary.

118
00:06:15,660 --> 00:06:20,310
But in, in our opinion here at ITProTV
there are other certifications that

119
00:06:20,310 --> 00:06:24,990
cover those areas in much more depth that
are much more widely known, all right?

120
00:06:24,990 --> 00:06:28,940
If you pass this one exam,
you get your MTA.

121
00:06:28,940 --> 00:06:34,020
If you pass all four of these exams,
you still have just one MTA.

122
00:06:34,020 --> 00:06:37,740
So, on your resume, it doesn't really make
a difference as far as which ones you

123
00:06:37,740 --> 00:06:39,370
pass here, you just need to pass one.

124
00:06:39,370 --> 00:06:43,010
And if you're just starting,
the Windows Operating System Fundamentals,

125
00:06:43,010 --> 00:06:44,470
that's really the best one.

126
00:06:44,470 --> 00:06:47,590
That's the one that, that gives
you the basic skills to get in and

127
00:06:47,590 --> 00:06:49,680

128
00:06:49,680 --> 00:06:54,880
If you wanna go on, well, Windows server
administration, you'll learn all about

129
00:06:54,880 --> 00:07:01,430
that in the MCSA track, the Microsoft

130
00:07:01,430 --> 00:07:01,986
Is that right Ronnie?

131
00:07:01,986 --> 00:07:03,020
>> Mm-hm, solutions associate, yep.

132
00:07:03,020 --> 00:07:04,010
>> Okay [LAUGH].
It, it changed.

133
00:07:04,010 --> 00:07:06,330
It used to be the Microsoft
Certified Systems Administrator and

134
00:07:06,330 --> 00:07:08,200
they changed the name so
I get a little tongue-tied there.

135
00:07:08,200 --> 00:07:12,050
But the MCSA, and that's where
you're learning all the nitty-gritty

136
00:07:12,050 --> 00:07:15,180
details about how to work on
the servers and general administration.

137
00:07:15,180 --> 00:07:17,350
And the MCSA is a much
better certification for

138
00:07:17,350 --> 00:07:19,390
that, and
we do cover that here at ITProTV.

139
00:07:20,960 --> 00:07:25,460
On the networking side, well,
there's the CompTIA Network+ and

140
00:07:25,460 --> 00:07:28,980
the Cisco CC enable, both of which
cover networking in great detail.

141
00:07:28,980 --> 00:07:30,630
And if you're gonna be a network engineer,

142
00:07:30,630 --> 00:07:32,710
those certifications are much better for
that.

143
00:07:32,710 --> 00:07:36,570
And look a lot better on the resume,
and so we cover that for networking.

144
00:07:36,570 --> 00:07:39,935
And on the security side,
there's the CompTIA Security+,

145
00:07:39,935 --> 00:07:43,630
which is internationally known,
very largely accepted as that

146
00:07:43,630 --> 00:07:47,360

gonna be a security professional.

147
00:07:47,360 --> 00:07:50,920
But if you're starting out with no
experience, nobody's gonna hire you to be

148
00:07:50,920 --> 00:07:54,230
a security professional without some
kind of resume to back that up.

149
00:07:54,230 --> 00:07:55,900
It's not a good starting point.

150
00:07:55,900 --> 00:07:59,630
And so,
we chose to not cover the remaining three

151
00:07:59,630 --> 00:08:02,560
because other certifications cover it and

152
00:08:02,560 --> 00:08:06,130
are more widely known, and
cover it in more depth and detail.

153
00:08:06,130 --> 00:08:08,440
You're certainly welcome to
pursue these certifications,

154
00:08:08,440 --> 00:08:10,840
we just don't necessarily
find a lot of value there.

155
00:08:10,840 --> 00:08:13,440
So, the Windows operating
system fundamentals,

156
00:08:13,440 --> 00:08:15,260
that's the one that creates the value.

157
00:08:15,260 --> 00:08:17,720
And so, that's what we're gonna
be covering here in this show.

158
00:08:17,720 --> 00:08:19,960
Over the next series of episodes,

159
00:08:19,960 --> 00:08:23,610
we're gonna film all of the content
that's covered by that exam.

160
00:08:23,610 --> 00:08:25,680
Everything that you need
to know to go in there and

161
00:08:25,680 --> 00:08:29,550
pass the exam on your first shot and
that's, that's really what we hope.

162
00:08:29,550 --> 00:08:32,140
We want people to make sure
they have good comprehension,

163
00:08:32,140 --> 00:08:36,910
understand the content, go in there and
pass, and kick off that IT career, right?

164
00:08:36,910 --> 00:08:38,380
Once you have this
certification under the belt,

165
00:08:38,380 --> 00:08:40,133
you're ready to rocket forward and
move in to the next one.

166
00:08:42,142 --> 00:08:45,235
All right, so let's, let's take
a look at that certification and

167
00:08:45,235 --> 00:08:46,384
what to entail, right?

168
00:08:46,384 --> 00:08:49,808
So, here is the 98-349 exam.

169
00:08:49,808 --> 00:08:51,520
That's the examination number.

170
00:08:51,520 --> 00:08:55,560
When you're ready to go and
pass this exam, you go to well,

171
00:08:55,560 --> 00:08:59,220
Pearson VUE is the company that
administers exams for Microsoft.

172
00:08:59,220 --> 00:09:01,550
Pearson VUE has centers
all over the world.

173
00:09:01,550 --> 00:09:06,501
You just go to their website,
which is VUE, VUE.com.

174
00:09:06,501 --> 00:09:10,264
And when you go to the VUE website,
they'll have in here where you can pick

175
00:09:10,264 --> 00:09:13,864
what vendor you're testing with and
we, we'll just say Microsoft.

176
00:09:13,864 --> 00:09:16,337
It'll be buried in here somewhere,
there we go.

177
00:09:16,337 --> 00:09:19,740
And you can go in and
start to sign up for a Microsoft exam.

178
00:09:19,740 --> 00:09:25,900
And you'll see there's the MTA exams, and
you'll be able to sign up and take it.

179
00:09:25,900 --> 00:09:26,986
All right?
You'll find a,

180
00:09:26,986 --> 00:09:28,540
a VUE center that is near you, right?

181
00:09:28,540 --> 00:09:31,855
So, so, there'll be one usually in your
city or a nearby city that you can go and

182
00:09:31,855 --> 00:09:32,840
take the exam at.

183
00:09:32,840 --> 00:09:35,410
I think there's two or
three of them here in Gainesville and

184
00:09:35,410 --> 00:09:39,020
we're in a really small city, so
they're, they're all over the place.

185
00:09:39,020 --> 00:09:40,480
But you'll go and you'll take that exam.

186
00:09:40,480 --> 00:09:43,830
Now, what do you need to know,
right, what, what's covered.

187
00:09:43,830 --> 00:09:47,450
Well, Microsoft publishes all
the information right here on

188
00:09:47,450 --> 00:09:52,397
their 98-349 page, and let you know
about where you can take at VUE.

189
00:09:52,397 --> 00:09:55,383
They list Prometric, but
that's ending soon, right?

190
00:09:55,383 --> 00:09:57,008
Do you remember, Ronnie [CROSSTALK],
it, it's actually right here.

191
00:09:57,008 --> 00:09:57,597
>> Yeah.

192
00:09:57,597 --> 00:10:00,310
>> December 31st, 2014.

193
00:10:00,310 --> 00:10:03,340
Depending on when you watch this video,
that may have already passed.

194
00:10:03,340 --> 00:10:04,570
When we're shooting it right now,

195
00:10:04,570 --> 00:10:06,750
if you're watching live,
that's a month from now.

196
00:10:06,750 --> 00:10:09,280
So, in about one month that's
not gonna be available anymore.

197
00:10:09,280 --> 00:10:11,550
So, you really need to
test with Pearson VUE.

198
00:10:13,200 --> 00:10:15,910
But they also list what's
covered on the exam.

199
00:10:15,910 --> 00:10:18,840
And you'll see where they
divided it up into six sections.

200
00:10:18,840 --> 00:10:22,260
Each one worth between 15 and
20% of the exam.

201
00:10:22,260 --> 00:10:25,005
And the exam questions are spread
across all these areas.

202
00:10:26,827 --> 00:10:30,000
All right, so Ronnie let,
let's do a quick review of these areas.

203
00:10:30,000 --> 00:10:31,000
Kind of what's expected.

204
00:10:31,000 --> 00:10:34,010
Because for some of you guys sitting out
there, you might already know this stuff.

205
00:10:34,010 --> 00:10:35,610
This might not be the right
certification for you.

206
00:10:35,610 --> 00:10:37,430
You might already be beyond it.

207
00:10:37,430 --> 00:10:38,030
Right?

208
00:10:38,030 --> 00:10:40,070
Doesn't mean you couldn't go take
the exam and get the certification,

209
00:10:40,070 --> 00:10:41,170
still looks good on the resume,

210
00:10:41,170 --> 00:10:43,810
but you might choose to move
to a more advanced one.

211
00:10:43,810 --> 00:10:47,198
So, let's, let's just kinda run down these
and, and see what else is involved, right?

212
00:10:47,198 --> 00:10:49,720
>> The first exam
objective that we have is,

213
00:10:49,720 --> 00:10:52,420
understanding operating
system configurations.

214
00:10:52,420 --> 00:10:54,480
And this is where we get
into the operating system.

215
00:10:54,480 --> 00:10:58,487
And we show you what you can do to
manipulate the operating system to change

216
00:10:58,487 --> 00:10:59,983
it better to suit the user.

217
00:10:59,983 --> 00:11:02,293
So, that they can do
everything that they need to.

218
00:11:02,293 --> 00:11:04,170
So, you'll see things like control panel.

219
00:11:04,170 --> 00:11:08,133
And we're gonna take a look at some of the
desktop settings where we can change that

220
00:11:08,133 --> 00:11:11,143
and make it look a little bit better,
for the user to be able to do.

221
00:11:11,143 --> 00:11:14,952
And then, we are going to get underneath
a little bit and take look at the native

222
00:11:14,952 --> 00:11:18,302
tools that are built in that allow
us to configure what start's up and

223
00:11:18,302 --> 00:11:19,778
some different items there.

224
00:11:19,778 --> 00:11:20,544
>> Yeah.

225
00:11:20,544 --> 00:11:24,354
And you'll see a lot of things in here
that our, our regular end used might not

226
00:11:24,354 --> 00:11:27,355
need but as a support personnel,
you more than likely will.

227
00:11:27,355 --> 00:11:31,750
Now, after that we move on to installing
and upgrading plan systems, right?

228
00:11:31,750 --> 00:11:34,048
We might need to reinstall windows.

229
00:11:34,048 --> 00:11:35,928
For your average consumer,
they buy a laptop or

230
00:11:35,928 --> 00:11:38,870
desktop and it's already installed
on there and they're fine.

231
00:11:38,870 --> 00:11:42,390
But in a company environment, you'll
oftentimes have to erase a machine and

232
00:11:42,390 --> 00:11:44,670
clean it up, you know,
get a new install on there.

233
00:11:44,670 --> 00:11:46,370
So, we'll cover that process, right?

234
00:11:46,370 --> 00:11:47,110
How we can install it,

235
00:11:47,110 --> 00:11:50,130
the different versions of Windows
that we have to worry about,

236
00:11:50,130 --> 00:11:53,510
how to do upgrades if we're actually
upgrading from one version to another.

237
00:11:53,510 --> 00:11:57,970
And we'll even touch on virtualization
which is a big hot topic

238
00:11:57,970 --> 00:11:59,470
in the enterprise sector right now.

239
00:11:59,470 --> 00:12:00,690
So, that's our real neat section.

240
00:12:01,700 --> 00:12:05,170
>> Our third exam objective
is on managing applications.

241
00:12:05,170 --> 00:12:08,480
When the applications programs that
we install in the system to help

242
00:12:08,480 --> 00:12:09,480
us do something specific,

243
00:12:09,480 --> 00:12:12,810
we wanna make sure that you know
how to install the applications.

244
00:12:12,810 --> 00:12:15,330
We also wanna make sure that
you understand how to uninstall

245
00:12:15,330 --> 00:12:16,425
applications if you need to.

246
00:12:16,425 --> 00:12:21,075
And then, when we run into issues,
what do we do when we actually do have

247
00:12:21,075 --> 00:12:23,795
applications when, when they're not
running the way that we need to?

248
00:12:23,795 --> 00:12:24,835
So, we'll take a brief look at that.

249
00:12:26,205 --> 00:12:27,255
>> All right.
And then, after that,

250
00:12:27,255 --> 00:12:29,095
we're gonna dive into managing files and

251
00:12:29,095 --> 00:12:32,098
folders which might sound like a,
a, a given.

252
00:12:32,098 --> 00:12:34,520
Most people know how to copy or
paste a file or

253
00:12:34,520 --> 00:12:35,790
move a file around on the hard drive.

254
00:12:35,790 --> 00:12:39,190
But we're gonna look at some other
things like permissions that can be set,

255
00:12:39,190 --> 00:12:42,810
different file systems file and
print sharing.

256
00:12:42,810 --> 00:12:45,290
So, sharing our, our data over a network.

257
00:12:45,290 --> 00:12:47,190
And even disc encryption,

258
00:12:47,190 --> 00:12:50,600
which is another important topic we're
hearing a lot about in the news lately.

259
00:12:50,600 --> 00:12:54,415
So, we'll get a chance to see how to
implement those safely and securely.

260
00:12:54,415 --> 00:12:55,960
>> Yeah.

261
00:12:55,960 --> 00:12:58,790
Our fourth one is going
to be managing devices.

262
00:12:58,790 --> 00:13:01,150
This is where we add in
peripheral devices, or

263
00:13:01,150 --> 00:13:05,140
things like hard drives, how we actually
store data on those hard drives,

264
00:13:05,140 --> 00:13:08,510
what do we need to make sure that
we're doing the, the proper storage.

265
00:13:08,510 --> 00:13:10,840
Also, how do we get data
out of our computers?

266
00:13:10,840 --> 00:13:12,970
We'll talk about how we print and

267
00:13:12,970 --> 00:13:16,460
what we need to do to make sure that
we print to the correct location, too.

268
00:13:16,460 --> 00:13:19,330
And even other devices that we might
find that we have to get the operating

269
00:13:19,330 --> 00:13:20,050
system to talk to.

270
00:13:21,105 --> 00:13:23,035
>> And then, the very last
section is this guy right here,

271
00:13:23,035 --> 00:13:25,235
understanding operating
system maintenance.

272
00:13:25,235 --> 00:13:28,032
And that says, just because your
computer's running fine today,

273
00:13:28,032 --> 00:13:29,515
doesn't mean it will be tomorrow.

274
00:13:29,515 --> 00:13:33,970
We need to take some basic steps to keep
our machines healthy and running smoothly.

275
00:13:33,970 --> 00:13:37,330
So, we'll see how to do backups and
recovery, in case we have a failure.

276
00:13:37,330 --> 00:13:40,110
How to do general maintenance
to keep things running smooth.

277
00:13:40,110 --> 00:13:41,227
And then, lastly,

278
00:13:41,227 --> 00:13:45,515
probably the most important section of
the whole certification is updates.

279
00:13:45,515 --> 00:13:49,182
Keeping your system up to date and
patched so that when there's a, a bug or

280
00:13:49,182 --> 00:13:52,259
a security exploit or
whatever that you're taking care of and

281
00:13:52,259 --> 00:13:55,650
that you don't get you're system
compromised or loose your data.

282
00:13:56,820 --> 00:14:02,455
So, all said and done, those six
areas cover quite a bit of stuff.

283
00:14:02,455 --> 00:14:05,285
And some of it is content
that you might already know,

284
00:14:05,285 --> 00:14:06,885
just through your basic use of Windows.

285
00:14:06,885 --> 00:14:08,665
And that's great,
that gives you a head start.

286
00:14:08,665 --> 00:14:11,865
But other parts might go beyond that
to show things that we use in a,

287
00:14:11,865 --> 00:14:14,825
in a work environment when
you have an IT career.

288
00:14:14,825 --> 00:14:18,265
And that's the part that we need to study,
make sure we understand,

289
00:14:18,265 --> 00:14:21,095
get some good comfort,
comfort, comfort level with.

290
00:14:21,095 --> 00:14:23,790
And then, jump in there and
pass that exam.

291
00:14:23,790 --> 00:14:28,210
Now, you're ready to go out and start
applying for jobs that are help desk,

292
00:14:28,210 --> 00:14:32,440
basic support, computer repair,
those type of entry level jobs.

293
00:14:32,440 --> 00:14:36,010
And I know it's not glorious, some people,
some of you guys out there might be saying

294
00:14:36,010 --> 00:14:39,070
it right now like, I don't wanna do that,
I wanna work on the server.

295
00:14:39,070 --> 00:14:40,280
Well, that's great.

296
00:14:40,280 --> 00:14:42,150
But you gotta work up to that.

297
00:14:42,150 --> 00:14:42,670
Right?

298
00:14:42,670 --> 00:14:45,460
You don't start at
a company as the president.

299
00:14:45,460 --> 00:14:47,320
You work your way up to
become the president.

300
00:14:47,320 --> 00:14:49,240
Right?
And that's how it is in IT.

301
00:14:49,240 --> 00:14:51,890
If you wanna be a network engineer or
a systems engineer,

302
00:14:51,890 --> 00:14:55,430
if you wanna be up at that higher level
designing networks and supporting

303
00:14:55,430 --> 00:15:00,020
the overall big picture, you gotta work up
to that, you've gotta get that experience.

304
00:15:00,020 --> 00:15:01,160
This is the starting point, right?

305
00:15:01,160 --> 00:15:03,250
This is where we begin, right?

306
00:15:03,250 --> 00:15:06,230
There, there is another certification
that we offer here on ITProTV

307
00:15:06,230 --> 00:15:09,320
called the CompTIA IT Fundamentals.

308
00:15:09,320 --> 00:15:12,170
It is also a great starting point.

309
00:15:12,170 --> 00:15:16,330
So, kind of compares really
well to the MTA, but

310
00:15:16,330 --> 00:15:20,790
the big difference here is with the MTA,
it is Microsoft only.

311
00:15:20,790 --> 00:15:23,377
Right.
We're just looking at Windows, which,

312
00:15:23,377 --> 00:15:25,703
over 80% of business computers run.

313
00:15:25,703 --> 00:15:28,700
So, you definitely,
it's something that you want to learn.

314
00:15:28,700 --> 00:15:32,750
But if you also wanna learn about other
operating systems, like Mac OS or

315
00:15:32,750 --> 00:15:36,900
Linux, well the CompTIA IT Fundamentals
is vendor neutral.

316
00:15:36,900 --> 00:15:41,270
So, it covers some of those
other OS's too, gives you that,

317
00:15:41,270 --> 00:15:43,230
that more broad view, right?

318
00:15:43,230 --> 00:15:47,030
Even though, even though Linux desktops
make up very small percentage of business

319
00:15:47,030 --> 00:15:51,750
machines and Mac desktops are even smaller
you know that, that changes over time.

320
00:15:51,750 --> 00:15:55,460
And who knows, maybe five years from now,
Linux will be the number one desktop, or

321
00:15:55,460 --> 00:15:56,880
Mac will be the number one desktop.

322
00:15:56,880 --> 00:15:58,060
Things change, right?

323
00:15:58,060 --> 00:15:59,650
So, it is a good idea to see that one.

324
00:15:59,650 --> 00:16:03,090
And it's a good idea to do that
certification in addition to this one.

325
00:16:03,090 --> 00:16:05,570
You may do both, but it's,
it's entirely up to you.

326
00:16:05,570 --> 00:16:09,800
So, if you haven't checked out CompTIA IT
Fundamentals, you might wanna review that.

327
00:16:09,800 --> 00:16:12,480
You know, we, we did an overview
video just like this for it.

328
00:16:12,480 --> 00:16:14,680
Review that and see which one is right for
you to start with,

329
00:16:14,680 --> 00:16:17,220
if you just wanna do one or
do both, you know?

330
00:16:17,220 --> 00:16:20,819
Both of them are fairly small sets of,
of information,

331
00:16:20,819 --> 00:16:23,817
easy to study for and
great way to get started.

332
00:16:23,817 --> 00:16:27,200
All right, well, if all of that sounds
exciting to you, I hope it does,

333
00:16:27,200 --> 00:16:29,260
we're excited to jump in and do it.

334
00:16:29,260 --> 00:16:31,500
And so, we are in the right place, right?

335
00:16:31,500 --> 00:16:34,600
We're ready to jump into our episodes and
we hope to see you there.

336
00:16:34,600 --> 00:16:36,980
If this doesn't sound right for
you, don't feel bad, right?

337
00:16:36,980 --> 00:16:38,240
Not every certification is for

338
00:16:38,240 --> 00:16:43,260
everyone, and just keep looking for
the one that's right for you.

339
00:16:43,260 --> 00:16:47,096
If you have any questions, right, if,
if any of this isn't certain to you or, or

340
00:16:47,096 --> 00:16:48,880
whatever, feel free to ask us.

341
00:16:48,880 --> 00:16:50,770
If you're an ITProTV subscriber,

342
00:16:50,770 --> 00:16:53,090
you can always go to the Q&A forums and
post there.

343
00:16:53,090 --> 00:16:56,320
You'll see the link that says
Q&A at the top of every page.

344
00:16:56,320 --> 00:16:59,470
You can click on that, post your questions
there and we monitor and answer.

345
00:16:59,470 --> 00:17:02,520
And we kind, kinda help, give you
guidance or suggestions, recommendations.

346
00:17:02,520 --> 00:17:05,010
Whatever it is that we can do to help.

347
00:17:05,010 --> 00:17:09,290
If you're not an ITProTV member yet, then
you won't be able to use the Q&A forums.

348
00:17:09,290 --> 00:17:13,260
So, instead, if you're just not certain,
shoot us a support ticket.

349
00:17:13,260 --> 00:17:15,920
There's a contact us link at
the bottom of every page and

350
00:17:15,920 --> 00:17:18,740
you can use that to open up
a support ticket and say, hey I'm,

351
00:17:18,740 --> 00:17:22,210
I'm thinking about subscribing and
I'm just uncertain about this, or this.

352
00:17:22,210 --> 00:17:23,410
And we'll, we'll help you out.

353
00:17:23,410 --> 00:17:26,063
We'll make sure you get the information
you need to be successful.

354
00:17:26,063 --> 00:17:29,465
It's really important you pick
the right certifications to,

355
00:17:29,465 --> 00:17:32,736
to start with cuz if you pick
the wrong ones at the beginning,

356
00:17:32,736 --> 00:17:35,299
it can really set you up for
a, a tough time, and

357
00:17:35,299 --> 00:17:37,813
you can get kind of disenfranchised or-
>> Overwhelmed.

358
00:17:37,813 --> 00:17:38,811
>> Whatever.
Yeah.

359
00:17:38,811 --> 00:17:39,890
You, you get overwhelmed.

360
00:17:39,890 --> 00:17:42,785
And then, then, you say,
IT is not right for me.

361
00:17:42,785 --> 00:17:45,565
And it could have been great, you could
have a really wonderful career there.

362
00:17:45,565 --> 00:17:47,245
And you just started
off on the wrong foot.

363
00:17:47,245 --> 00:17:49,965
So, you know,
we definitely wanna help with that.

364
00:17:49,965 --> 00:17:50,875
All right.
Well,

365
00:17:50,875 --> 00:17:52,277
we're excited to get into the episode.

366
00:17:52,277 --> 00:17:53,683
So, enough stalling around.

367
00:17:53,683 --> 00:17:58,920
Stay tuned, we've got MTA episodes
coming up and we'll see you then.

368
00:17:58,920 --> 00:18:04,789
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes walk you through many of the Control Panel options and their configurations. They begin by looking at Administrative Tools like Computer Management, Event Viewer, and Services. They also show you a few administrative storage utilities like Disk Cleanup, Defrag, and iSCSI initiator.
episodes.title: Configure Control Panel Options

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue configuring Windows 10 Control Panel options, picking back up with Administrative Tools, then Accessibility features, Power settings, and finally File Explorer settings.
episodes.title: Configure Control Panel Options Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes finish taking you through configurable Control Panel options. They jump back in by looking at Accessibility Options like the Narrator, Magnifier, and Visual options. Next they tackle configuring the Power Settings like power profiles and custom power plans, and then File Explorer settings like the Ribbon and Quick Access menus.
episodes.title: Configure Control Panel Options Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes dive into the desktop settings for Windows 10. They start by explaining user profiles and configuring display resolution, orientation, and color management. Next they explore configuring and customizing the Start Menu and Task Bar.
episodes.title: Configure Desktop Settings

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore a few of the native applications and tools found in Windows 10. They start with common accessories like notepad, paint, snipping tool, and Internet Explorer. Then they look at the bells and whistles found in the new Microsoft Edge web-browser.
episodes.title: Configure Native Applications and Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue their rundown of native applications and tools in Windows 10. They jump back in by exploring Microsoft's digital assistant, Cortana. Next, they take a look at the MSCONFIG utility which allows you to do things like modify how Windows boots up and manage Services. Then they demonstrate working with the Task Manager.
episodes.title: Configure Native Applications and Tools Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes finish their exploration of Windows 10 native applications and tools. They pick up by walking you through the Computer Management console. Here you'll have access to tools like the Task Scheduler, Event Viewer, Device Manager, User and Group management, as well as Storage and Services interfaces.
episodes.title: Configure Native Applications and Tools Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce the virtualization concepts and Microsoft’s Hyper-V.  They show that uses and benefits of virtualization technology.  They briefly discuss some of the terms and general concepts then show how to find Hyper-V and configure some of  settings in a virtual machine, such as adding RAM and expanding the size of the virtual HD.
episodes.title: Configure Hyper-V

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes discuss and demonstrate some of the key mobility settings you can find when Windows is running on a mobile platform such as a laptop.  These features help with extending battery life and staying connected to resources such as other computers and even files when there is no connection to the network, according to the team.  They demonstrate the use of Remote Desktop Connection, using the Mobility Center and how to Synchronize files when the mobile device and network resource is connected back to the network.
episodes.title: Configure Mobility Settings

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce us to some of the management tools found in the Windows Operating System.  Wes shows and describes the use of the Microsoft Management Console to manage the OS.  Also introduced are the command line interpreters:  the command prompt; Powershell and Powershell ISE as a powerful way to manage the operating system without dependence on the GUI.
episodes.title: Configure and Use Management Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take a look into the system requirements, editions and upgrade paths for Windows Operating Systems.   They talk about and show the importance of understanding the minimum requirements for an operating system.  Wes also describes some of the different editions of Windows-based desktop operating systems and the choices a company or user has.  The team also talks about the use of upgrade paths, which is normally found in the home environment rather than the business environment.
episodes.title: Requirements, Editions and Upgrades

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes describe the different media options to install a Windows OS and installation types.  They describe the use of optical media, usb drive and  network installation.  Then, Wes describes a clean install, an upgrade and migration as different types of possible installations.  The team includes a demonstration of the migration type of installation.
episodes.title: Understand Installation Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take a look at the Windows Operating System Architecture.  They take the time to break the operating system down into fundamental parts of the user mode, kernel mode, hardware abstraction layer that runs on the hardware.  The team emphasizes why it’s important and how it affects the use of RAM and additional hardware.  This division is foundational to way the operating system can continue to function even in light of an application crash.
episodes.title: Understand Operating System Architecture

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes discuss some of the different types of software installation files that are available.  They also demonstrate how to run the installation from an .exe, .msi and even a Windows Store app.  Also, the team briefly discusses the context of installation the use of the UAC, the User Account Control.
episodes.title: Configuring Application and the UAC

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes continue with a part 2.  This time, they pickup on some of the more security related settings and windows features that are built into the operating system itself.  The team emphasizes this because an important part of keeping your network secure is keeping regular desktops secure as well.  They show how to enable windows features, and configure smart screen technology.  Lastly, the team briefly demonstrates and describes the different settings available for configuring the UAC.
episodes.title: Configuring Application and the UAC Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce us to the Windows Defender, Windows Firewall, and Services.  These are principle services and applications that run to allow users to operate on Windows.  Wes describes the built in antivirus and how it functions as well as the different configuration settings possible with the Firewall.  Lastly, they take a look into the world of services that the operating system depends on to insure it functions the way it should.
episodes.title: Configure Antivirus, Firewalls and Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes discuss the interdependent  relationship of File Systems and Permissions.  The file system, if choosing NTFS gives the ability to not only store and retrieve files but also NTFS permissions, according to the team.  Wes also explains and demonstrates the NTFS permissions in action and the results when setting different permissions.
episodes.title: File Systems, Permissions and Sharing

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take a look at setting up share permissions.  They begin with configuring file and printer sharing on the resource machine to allow for access.  Also, they show how to connect to the resource computer using the UNC path and mapping a network drive.  They also discuss the use of share permissions to grant access to the network resource.  The emphasize when connecting from a remote computer to the network resource, the most restrictive of the NTFS Permissions and Share permissions apply.
episodes.title: File Systems, Permissions and Sharing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Wes look at how to configure libraries in File Explorer as well as map additional network locations such as an FTP site. They will also look at how to setup and configure  HomeGroups within Windows.
episodes.title: File Systems, Permissions and Sharing Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike discuss encryption methods. They look at whole disk encryption using Bitlocker, and the difference between TPM and non-TPM modes. They demonstrate configuring Bitlocker.
episodes.title: Understanding Encryption

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their look at encryption. They demonstrate how to recover a Bitlocker protected drive. They also look at file level encryption, using Encrypting File System (EFS).
episodes.title: Understanding Encryption Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike discuss the different types of storage in computer systems. They look at storage device types, and their connectivity method. They also look at common partitioning schemes, and demonstrate methods to partition a storage device.
episodes.title: Understanding Storage

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue to discuss the different types of storage in computer systems. They discuss tools such as DISKPART and technologies such as simple and spanned volumes.
episodes.title: Understanding Storage Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes take a look at supporting printers in Windows 10. Here you will learn the difference between a print driver and a print spooler, a printer and a print device, and a local vs network printer. They also things like print queues, Print-to-File, and Internet printing.
episodes.title: Understanding Printing Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore the importance of backups, recovery, and updates in Windows 10. They start by taking you through the necessary steps to perform a System Restore, create a Recovery Drive, and boot into Safe Mode, exploring the details of when/why each are utilized.
episodes.title: Backup, Recovery and Updates

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue exploring backups, recovery, and updates in Windows 10. They jump back in by showing you how to perform a file recovery via OneDrive. They also show you how to manage your updates, install and/or rollback drivers, and look at Current Branch and Insider Preview.
episodes.title: Backup, Recovery and Updates Part 2
